whatIs.title: What Is a Vehicle Bill of Sale?
content: A vehicle bill of sale is a signed receipt that:
Transfers ownership from seller to buyer
Documents key facts (price, VIN, mileage, “as-is” notice, etc.)
Triggers title & registration at your state DMV
Protects both parties against future tax, lien, or liability disputes
Think of it as your proof of ownership and condition on the day the keys change hands.

why.title: Why You Need One (Even in “Handshake” States)

headers: Risk Without a Bill of Sale
rows: Can’t prove you no longer own the car—tickets or tolls still arrive in your name
Timestamped document shows the exact moment you transferred ownership
Buyer claims undisclosed damage
“As-is” clause and inspection notes limit liability
DMV rejects title transfer due to missing data
Template is pre-mapped to every DMV field

covered.title: Which Vehicles Are Covered?
covered.content: Cars • Trucks • Motorcycles • Boats • RVs • ATVs • Trailers • Snowmobiles • Personal Watercraft—any motorized or towable vehicle that needs a title or registration.

types.title: Five Common Bill of Sale Types
items: Standard Sale – cash or certified funds, no warranties
As-Is Sale – buyer accepts current condition, zero guarantees
Gift Transfer – records $0 or token price, tracks mileage and tax exemptions
Dealer Sale – includes dealership info & statutory warranties
Odometer Disclosure – federally required if the vehicle is < 10 years old

rows: Full Legal Names & Addresses
DMV and tax offices reject partial info
Vehicle Description (make, model, year, body type, color, VIN, odometer)
Prevents title fraud and clerical errors
Purchase Price & Payment Method
Sets sales-tax basis and proves consideration
As-Is / Warranty Language
Shields seller from future mechanical claims
Lien Status & Release
Confirms the buyer receives clear title
Delivery Details
Specifies when and where risk of loss passes
Signatures (and Notary if required)
Makes the document enforceable

checklist.title: Buyer & Seller Checklist
items: Verify legal names match driver’s licenses
Confirm VIN on dash matches title
Remove license plates before delivery (seller)
Cancel insurance only after title transfer (seller)
Obtain temporary insurance before driving home (buyer)
File title application within state deadline (both)

q1.question: Do I really need a bill of sale if my state doesn’t ask for one?
q1.answer: Yes. It proves ownership transfer, protects you from future tickets, and sets the tax basis even in handshake states.

q2.question: Is online notarization available?
q2.answer: Absolutely. Add the Remote Notary upgrade at checkout and sign via webcam in minutes.

q3.question: Can I save the form and finish later?
q3.answer: Yes. Your progress auto-saves to your secure 123LegalDoc account for 30 days.

q4.question: Does the template include the odometer disclosure?
q4.answer: For vehicles under 10 years old, the federal odometer statement is auto-inserted as a separate page.

q5.question: What if I’m gifting the car?
q5.answer: Select “Gift” in Step 3. The price auto-sets to $0 and triggers the proper tax-exemption language.
